questions.text: What are the two basic characteristics of a vector?
questions.explanation:
magnitude and direction.

	A scalar quantity, which has only size, is any ordinary number like 13 or -2. A vector would be something like 15 mph going NNE, or 3 in the direction of 85 degrees above the horizontal. The magnitude of a vector is an absolute value: it's never negative.

questions.text: Vectors are often split into two or more orthogonal components. What is true of these components in relation to each other?
questions.explanation:
They are perpendicular.

	The vector itself can be thought of as the hypotenuse of a right triangle, where the two legs are the components. In Cartesian coordinates, a vector is expressed in terms of its {coordinates;} a size-2 vector in the y-direction would be (0,2) -- 0 directed along the x-axis and 2 directed along the y-axis.

questions.text: Where 'a' is the length of the vector and 'B' is the angle it makes with the x-axis, what is the length of its component along the x-axis?
questions.explanation:
a cosB.

	This comes from basic trigonometry. The length of the component along the y-axis would be a*sinB.

As arrows.

	This method allows both magnitude (the length of the arrow) and direction to be represented.

questions.correct: a vector with a magnitude of 1
options: a vector in the horizontal direction
a vector with uniform curvature (like an arc of a circle)
equal to one one-thousandth of a kilovector
questions.explanation:
a vector with a magnitude of 1.

	Unit vectors are used to define direction. The three most commonly used are i, j, and k, defining the directions of the x, y, and z axes, respectively.

questions.text: How do you add two vectors graphically?
questions.correct: Place them head-to-tail and draw the addition vector from the tail of one to the head of the other.
options: This can't be done; vectors can only be added algebraically.
Place them head-to-tail and draw the addition vector from the head of one to the tail of the other.
Place them tail-to-tail and draw the addition vector connecting the two heads.
questions.explanation:
Place them head-to-tail and draw the addition vector from the tail of one to the head of the other.

	Remember, the direction of the addition vector is as important as its length. The addition of two vectors is equivalent to traveling the vectors consecutively: you eventually reach the same place relative to your starting point.

questions.text: How do you add two vectors algebraically?
questions.correct: Break the vectors into components. Then add x-components, y-components, etc, algebraically.
options: Break the vectors into components, then add the lengths of all of them together.
This can't be done; vectors can only be added graphically.
Add each of the characteristics from Q1.
questions.explanation:
Break the vectors into components. Then add x-components, y-components, etc, algebraically.

	This method is also called component addition. Analysis reveals that this method is mathematically equivalent to the graphical method.

questions.text: The norm of a vector, found by taking the square root of the sum of the squares of the components, is equal to what quantity?
questions.explanation:
magnitude.

	The norm of vector r is often indicated by enclosing r in absolute-value signs. A Euclidean norm is found by the method described above - you'll encounter other varieties of norms as you progress in math and physics, but they're all equal to the magnitude.

questions.text: The dot product is used to multiply two vectors for a scalar result. When you dot vectors r and s, with angle Q between them, the answer is equal to which of the following values?
questions.explanation:
(norm of r) (norm of s) (cosQ).

	Another way to calculate the dot product is by multiplying the x-components by each other, the y-components by each other, and so on -- then you add all the products. It's interesting to note that the dot product of any two perpendicular vectors is zero.

questions.text: The cross product is a way of multiplying two vectors for a result that is a vector. What geometrical quantity does its length represent?
questions.correct: area of the parallelogram defined by the two vectors
options: statistical mean of the two vectors
area of the triangle defined by the two vectors
area of the circle sector defined by the two vectors
questions.explanation:
area of the parallelogram defined by the two vectors.

	The cross product is defined only in three dimensions and higher, since that vector is always perpendicular to both the original two vectors. So if you drew two vectors on a sheet of paper and took their cross product, the resultant would either rise out of or sink into the page. The magnitude has the value (magnitude of r)(magnitude of s)(sinQ).
